results.title: What Is a Motor Vehicle Record (MVR)? | Progressive
results.description: Better known as your driving record, your MVR includes any moving violations, traffic tickets, and accidents you've had either within a given time period or throughout your driving history.

results.title: What Is a Clean Driving Record? | Progressive
results.description: A clean driving record is defined as a motor vehicle record (MVR) with no violations, at-fault accidents, or traffic-related convictions for a set amount of time. It's the ideal situation for any driver, but a violation doesn't completely negate ...

results.title: Can You Get a Refund on Car Insurance? | Progressive
results.description: There can be multiple reasons why an insurance company cancels your policy, including having too many accidents or tickets on your driving record, getting a DUI, or failing to pay your premium.

results.title: How Much Is Car Insurance? | Progressive
results.description: Accidents and tickets can increase your insurance premium. New drivers with no record may also pay more.

results.title: How Much Does Insurance Go Up After an Accident? | Progressive
results.description: In general, insurance companies look back at several years of your driving history when determining your car insurance rate. The amount of time an accident remains on your driving record, which can be used to determine your car insurance rate, may vary by your state and insurer.
